answers.author: Dustin Anderson
answers.text:
Greenwich distributes our agenda and non-executive Board of Selectmen (city councils out west) agenda and packets to press and our website no later than 72 hours before the time of the meeting. Selectmen receive their executive (pending litigation, etc.) agendas and packets in advance of that. All public meeting notices are also posted electronically. 
However, there are a number of factors that prevent total paperless BOS meetings. First, Connecticut has robust public meeting notification requirements, so electronic posting alone will not satisfy the law. Secondly, and more importantly, the generational diversity in Town and strong tradition of civic engagement preclude any discussion of doing away with the hard copy of anything. We simply would not be delivering a desired service if we stopped producing paper copies of the agenda for the public. 
Please forgive me if I misunderstood your question.

answers.author: Richard Brown
answers.text:
We post our agendas on our web site and the secretary of state's web site at least 48 hours prior to a meeting.  This has helped reduce the need to make paper agendas available to the public and allows them to come to the meeting knowing what items will be discussed.
I am on one board that has gone completely paperless.   About a week before the meeting we receive an email letting board members know that content on on a secure portion of the web site.  The agency provides laptops at the meetings ( and to take home) for those members that need them.

answers.author: Zane Reynolds
answers.text:
The city of Hampton, Virginia distributed IPads to all council members and senior management in order to move to a completely paperless council agenda process. 
From my brief conversations with the jurisdiction they are indeed realizing savings and reporting that the IPads will pay for themselves in as little as six months. In addtion to the cost savings realized, they are also indicating that council meetings are running more smoothly as members require less time to flip through large paper agendas. Bookmarks and shortcuts can easily be inserted to a single PDF document that is distributed to all members of the meeting.
For more information on this you should contact John Eagle in Hampton, VA.

answers.author: Mark Barham
answers.text:
The City of Williamsburg makes the City Council agendas available online in PDF format from the City Council area of the City website, http://www.williamsburgva.gov.  Additionally, we no longer print paper City Council agenda packets for City Council or City staff.  We now distribute these agenda packets via our website to City provided iPads to City Council members.  They can then read the packet as well as make annotations on the packet.  Staff that are requried to attend City Council meetings receive their packets this way as well.

author: Maya Williams
text:
To what extent has your city used technology to aid in agenda distribution, especially your city council, board of supervisors, and/or the equivalent?
We've heard of some cities using Kendalls to go paperless with council agendas.  Are other cities considering similiar initiatives or other to go paperless?  Please advise.
